sub_topic: Calculation of the Bohr radius in hydrogen atom
message_1: What is the Bohr radius of a hydrogen atom in meters, given its atom number Z = 1 and its electron mass is 9.11 x 10^-31 kg?
message_2:
The Bohr radius (a₀) of a hydrogen atom is given by the formula:

a₀ = (4πε₀ħ²) / (m_eZe²)

where:
ε₀ = vacuum permittivity (8.854 x 10^-12 C²/Nm²)
ħ = reduced Planck constant (1.055 x 10^-34 Js)
m_e = electron mass (9.11 x 10^-31 kg)
Z = atomic number (1 for hydrogen)
e = elementary charge (1.602 x 10^-19 C)

Plugging in the values, we get:

a₀ = (4π(8.854 x 10^-12)(1.055 x 10^-34)²) / ((9.11 x 10^-31)(1)(1.602 x 10^-19)²)

a₀ ≈ 5.291772 x 10^-11 m

So, the Bohr radius of a hydrogen atom is approximately 5.291772 x 10^-11 meters.
